Lack of specific information: The expert notes that the article in question did not provide any specific details about which national security agencies went on "high alert" or what actions they took. This lack of specific information raises doubts about the authenticity of the claim.
Reliance on clickbait headline: The expert highlights that the Bipartisan Report article relied heavily on a sensationalized clickbait headline to grab attention. This suggests that the article may have prioritized generating views and clicks over providing accurate and verified information.
Source of the claim: The expert points out that the claim originated from a post shared by activist and journalist Shaun King. However, the post did not mention any national security agency action or provide any new information to support the claim. This raises questions about the credibility and reliability of the source.
Contextual information: The expert mentions that the video shared by Shaun King alongside the claim was edited to include statements made by Donald Trump about his relationship with Vladimir Putin. However, the expert notes that these statements were taken out of context and did not provide any evidence of a dangerous lie or compromised national security. This suggests that the claim may have been exaggerated or misrepresented.
